Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Multiplayer vs. Single-Player iVR Training for Surgical Skills Acquisition

Trial_Design.evidence: In a randomised controlled trial, 40 participants were allocated to either individual or team iVR training using block randomisation with a 1:1 ratio.

Participants.evidence: Participants included junior orthopedic surgical residents and novice scrub technicians.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention involved five iVR training sessions over six weeks, followed by a real-world assessment of anterior approach total hip arthroplasty on a high-fidelity model.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates whether multiplayer immersive Virtual Reality (iVR) training surpasses single-player training in acquiring technical and nontechnical skills for complex surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Non-Operative Technical Skills for Surgeons (NOTSS) score, assessed by two blinded observers.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 40 participants were allocated to either individual or team iVR training using block randomisation with a 1:1 ratio.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Team-trained participants demonstrated superior nontechnical skills (NOTSS: 13.1±1.5 vs 10.6±1.6, P = 0.002) and completed procedures 33% faster (28.2 minutes ± 5.5 vs 41.8 ± 8.9, P < 0.001) with fewer technical errors (10.4 ± 6.1 vs 22.6 ± 5.4, P < 0.001).
